summary: Have you read that TV Guide interview? Kit said that the Jon/Arya reunion won’t be all warm and fuzzy and that maybe they’re...
question: Have you read that TV Guide interview? Kit said that the Jon/Arya reunion won’t be all warm and fuzzy and that maybe they’re reunion won’t be “what we want them to be”. 😩
answer:
Yeah I have. Listen love, don’t take cast interviews to heart. They know their words play a massive role in promoting the season and creating a hype. It gets people talking, and boy, have they got tumblr and twitter in a frenzy. Almost never do these interviews give away major plot points, but simply create a ‘will they/won’t they’ debate.

But if I’m going to play the devil’s advocate here and take the interview into consideration, I can also say that I’m not worried. Yes, Arya and Jon have changed, and it might take a little time to navigate around the people they’ve become. I say this as a Jonrya shipper too.

Bear in mind, book!Arya already thinks Jon wouldn’t recognise her - but she still believes he loves her. Jon, likewise, wonders the same. But we know how much they care about each other. That’s fundamental to their relationship: that when they were unwanted by others, they found acceptance together. That’s not something that’s going to change because it’s the building blocks of what makes their bond so special.

However, Arya’s less open and Jon’s more solemn and both are traumatized af after everything they’ve been through. Both have been disillusioned and betrayed and stabbed and suffered, and when that happens, it wreaks havoc on one’s ability to connect to those around them. Kit’s got a point in that people are expecting Season 1 or AGOT Jon/Arya, the one where they’re happily teasing each other and free with their embraces. Warm and fuzzy.

But after everything they’ve been through, can we blame them if they need a little time to open themselves up again like they used to? It’s not unreasonable, and the show hasn’t really done anything for their relationship like the books have. They need the audience to see this relationship grow, to evolve and go through trials and tests to demonstrate the strength of their bond and how no matter what, they’ll support each other. It’s storytelling, after all.

It’s easy to forget that most of the GA haven’t actually read the books and don’t really know their history as well. It puts everything into perspective then. So please don’t worry! I’m fairly confident that things will turn out alright :)

body:
GOT Endgame Theory

I’m sure someone has thought about this, but it just popped into my mind… what if instead of the whole Dany and Jon arch happening, it’s Dany and Sansa ? Like obvi Dany and Jon had sex and that’s like a while thing, but what about after they find out they are related and she is his aunt ? I love Dany and I want her to find her place on the throne but I also love the Starks and I think the North will only follow along with everyone else if a Stark in on the throne in the end because they loyal af. We already somewhat know that Dany isn’t necessarily against having relationships with women based on season one (she was totally into the girl that was teaching her to please Drogo) and when the Greyjoys pledged their loyalties to her, Yara flirted and somewhat suggested marriage (Dany blushed and didn’t openly object to the idea at least from what I remember); moving on to Sansa, this is just guessing but with her as well, I don’t think we have seen her openly deny the possibility of her having relations with a woman, I know she hasn’t in the past but after all her experiences with men, she might be more open to it then we think ? If this were to happen then there would be a Targaryen and a Stark on the throne, I feel like this would please the audience (to an extent) and defs the North because they love Sansa. Along with this, if this were to happen I would guess that Jon would die but Dany would be pregnant with his child, whom would later become the rightful heir to the throne (with Targaryen and Stark blood) and be raised by Dany and Sansa (a Targaryen and a Stark). As for the Lannisters, I hope Cersei dies but Jamie becomes maybe like Hand to the Queens, and Gindry and Aria live happily ever after as badass mercenaries with ninja assassin babies 👊🏼

summary: Something about the last sentence kept bugging me and I couldn't understand what and then it clicked and I was like COULD IT...
body:
Something about the last sentence kept bugging me and I couldn’t understand what and then it clicked and I was like COULD IT BE?!?????

Sophie has it hanging at home.

No one’s noticed.

Why did she mention it at all?

How do you not notice an entire new storyboard hanging on a wall in your house?

Could it be because -

In Sansa’s dreams, her children looked just like the brothers she had lost. Sometimes there was even a girl who looked like Arya.

It’s a STORYBOARD.

Meaning, it’s DRAWN PICTURES. SKETCHES.

If it’s Jon and Sansa and their children on a storyboard OF COURSE no one will take a second look, thinking it’s just the Starks we have known, not guessing it’s the next generation!

She didn’t mean no one from her family and friends that visit her noticed an entire new frame on the wall in her house. She meant no one noticed it’s from a new scene of the new season!

title: Game of Throne: ENDGAME
body:
There’s a quote from Sophie Turner going around about how her favorite scene is the final scene in the series and that she has the storyboard hanging in her home but no one has noticed. 

Think through this logically… everyone going into Sophie’s house knows she plays Sansa Stark on the very popular Game of Thrones.

Everyone who knows about Game of Thrones wants to know the ending.

So in what reality would visitor’s to Sophie’s house not notice the ending to the series hanging on Sophie’s wall? There’s really only one answer…

… the final image is something everyone is already so familiar with that no one thinks of it as the ending.

Something like, oh, maybe… someone sitting on the Iron Throne?

From season one on the iconic pose of characters sitting on the Iron Throne as the characters’ fortunes rise and fall has illustrated who the power players are in each season. Ned Stark (Sean Bean) had a turn. Now Jon Snow (Kit Harrington) is mimicking his foster-father’s pose. 

This might be a bad sign for our boy Jon Snow. Ned didn’t survive season one. 

Now look at the poster for Sansa for season 8. She’s wearing her season eight armor - the scales of House Tully with the wolf accents from House Stark (her mother and father respectively). She’s wearing her wheel necklace again, quite possibly a reference to the wheel of power that Daenerys wants to break. She’s looking straight ahead… it’s telling.

Because this is an image that could sit on Sophie’s wall and no one would ever question. 


The necklace seems important because it first appears when Sansa decides to enter the game of thrones. The first version had a broken circle (or broken wheel) as Daenerys promised. 

In later seasons, as Sansa reunites with her family and returns to her name and power, the wheel becomes unbroken.


More than that, Sansa’s ascension to the throne would make narrative sense. 

Sansa is - more than anyone in the series - the uniting force. She’s the only leader who has successfully got warring groups to work together.

Sansa was trained to rule. Jon, Dany, Cersei… none of them were actually taught to rule or care for their people. Sansa has learned from the greatest (and worst) political leaders of the age and she knows how to lead, listen, and resolve conflict.

Sansa is the queen meant for peace. Dany - as amazing as she is - is Stormborn. Her entire arc is one of war, destruction, and loss. For every victory she loses something. Her victories are always Pyrrhic (look it up). Short of killing everyone there is no way for Dany to live peacefully. My guess is she’ll sacrifice herself in battle and die with her dragons (sorry). 

Sansa is the the “younger, more beautiful queen” that Cersei has always feared. The title could have been Margaery Tyrell’s but Cersei nipped that in the bud. And Dany, despite being young and beautiful, technically belongs to the same generation as Cersei. She’s more beautiful, but not younger in the prophetic sense. Sansa is. She’s also Cersei’s foil… they’ve followed similar life paths (promised to one man, traded to another, abused, sold, betrayed). But where Cersei chooses fear, hate, and violence Sansa uses loyalty, love, and kindness to get what she needs (along with a healthy does of sisterly support from Arya). 
- Bonus - one of the first interactions between Cersei and Sansa has Cersei complimenting Sansa’s sewing skill and saying, “You must sew something for me.” And I hope what Sansa sews for her is a golden shroud fitting of the lion queen who won’t survive season eight. 


What does it mean if Sansa takes the throne? 

Sadly, it means a lot of our favorites won’t make it. 

Jon Snow and Dany are probably both doomed, as they are the major contenders for the throne now. For Sansa to take the throne they would both need to be dead or incapacitated in some way (unless you think either would step aside). In the poster Sansa is wearing all-black, which could be mourning clothes. 

Tyrion is headed for his third trial and is unlikely to survive, but maybe. I like him.

Arya and Bran have the best chance of survival if Sansa is queen. It also means The Hound and Brienne of Tarth have a better chance of survival since they both would fit in Sansa’s court. But these are just Best Guesses. 

So… what do you think?

Did Sophie Turner tell us the ending to Game of Thrones?

blog.name: springwolvesofwinterfell
blog.title: Spring comes to Winterfell
blog.description: My personal collection of GoT/ ASoIaF

title: Jorah’s choice (P3)
body:
Part 1

Part 2

In part 1, we speculated the events that might soon happen once Dany arrived North (#1 Dany’s dragons and/or the Dothraki do some harms to the Northerners; and #2 Tensions between Dany and the Northern lords including Lyanna Mormont because of #1) causing the first cracks in Jorah-Dany relationship.

In part 2, we revisited the life of Lord Commander Mormont, Jorah’s father and the father figure to both Jon and Sam, whose life and dedication practically bonds Jorah with his father’s two surrogate sons. We also examined how the relationship with their respective father (Ned, Jeor, Randyll) and the desire to carry the ancestral sword (Ice, Longclaw, Heartsbane) shaped Jon, Jorah and Sam’s character development and would be another bonding factor between the three sons. It’s highly likely that Sam will bestow his ancestral sword Heartsbane to Jorah. And this act of kindness will boost up Jorah’s morale and motivation to fight for the side of the living, to honor his father, and to pay his debt to Sam. 

Bromance or Romance, Family or Khaleesi

As discussed in part 1, tensions in the North between Dany and the lords would escalate shortly after her arrival while the Dead Army is approaching. Everyone starts to be wary of Dany and her dragons. And to boil up the already messy situation: 

# 3 News about Dany roasting the Lannister army and the Tarlys reaches the North

One way or the other, the lords will know about how Dany dracarys-ed the Lannister army and forced the survivors to kneel by executing the Tarlys with fire. Most probably from the maesters in Citadel who have been in contact with maester Wolkan in Winterfell. Everyone will be shocked, bad memories of the Mad King and all the terrible Targaryen rulers before him will be recalled and distrust of Dany and her “good will” would grow exponentially. 

Imagine what Jorah would think when he knows that his beloved Khaleesi, who always claimed to make the world a better place and free people from oppression, has done this horrible thing to thousands of men, many of them are just innocent commoners who were dragged into someone else’s war. 

Gif:  mockingjaykatniss2

What did he say to Dany when trying to convince her not to order the execution of thousands of masters in Yunkai when they rised against her?

Moreover, Jorah insisted that if building a better world was what Dany wanted, she had to show people (from both sides) another way, different from the brutality they had always known.

The slaves you freed, brutality is all they’ve ever known. If you want them to know something else, you’ll have to show it to them. (Jorah to Dany, 4x07)

Mind you, he was explaining her why punishing thousands of slavers, who were obviously criminals was a bad idea. She listened to him in Meereen, but does the exactly the opposite in Westeros, where her opponents are no slavers, making her actions of brutalizing them even worse. And here’s how she takes his wise counsel to heart and shows the people something different from brutality?? 

Gif:  urvi531

Jorah has to be totally disappointed at his ability as an adviser by now.

He would not be cool with the knowledge that Dany had slaughtered thousands of soldiers with a rain of fire while she obviously could win the battle without deploying her dragon. Not to mention what happened in the aftermath, when she continued to threaten the prisoners and executed their generals with dragon fire. To instill fear and force submission. His trust and respect in Dany would gradually deteriorate. 

Note that due to his leave to find a cure for himself, Jorah was not present in both scenes where Dany introduced herself as a fierce, merciless warlord. The writers kept him out for a reason. They want to reserve his reactions for a later date when the news and/or the reality would shock him. Jorah would shudder when he knows how brutal Dany has become and he cannot be at ease at all, if Dany plans to keep her word and does exactly the same to the North.

Like when she gave her rousing speech to the Dothraki about “kill my enemies in their iron suits and tear down their stone houses”…

Gif:  yocalio

… and the infamous “bend the knee or die”…

Does she sound any more like the compassionate queen who aspired to build a better world for the downtrodden that he once believed in? Does she sound any less brutal than all the sh*t leaders he already knew throughout the course of history?

Now Jorah knows exactly what Dany would do to those who do not kneel. He would be more worried than ever for the Little Bear since she might be in direct confrontation with Dany on various issues. Moreover, he would be very ashamed of himself and his Queen, and feel indebted to Sam, the one who saved his life and honored him with the Tarlys’ ancestral sword.

If the maesters in Citdel didn’t have the heart to inform Sam, then Jorah would find it a hundred time harder to face his savior after this news breaks out.

Despite his difficult relationship with his father, I bet Sam would be horrified and devastated when he learns about the fate of his father and brother. And I don’t believe he would keep his cool and stay silent “for the greater good”. Very likely, Sam will confront Dany, question her decision and/ or demand an explanation/ apology from her. I’m not sure if he would take a more reckless action toward Dany, but whatever he does, Sam puts himself in a very dangerous position when he personally confronts the Mother of Dragons.

When all these chaos happen, Jorah would try to give Dany counsel and calm her down (like he always did). But now Dany has fully embraced her identity as a dragon (as Lady Olenna advised her), she wouldn’t listen to him any more. 

And this is when Jorah finally sees Dany for what she is: A Dragon.

They’re dragons, Khaleesi. They can never be tamed. (Jorah to Dany, 4x01)

Dragons don’t know the difference between what is theirs and what isn’t. (Jorah to Missandei, 7x07)

This whole situation will be a hot mess, since lots of people in Winterfell had awful experience and/ or memories with fire fanatics. Jon, Davos, Tormund, Sansa, Arya, Bran, Gendry, Sandor, all the Northern lords, etc. And if Sam is under threat from Dany, who would find themselves responsible to protect him?

Jon, of course, Sam is his best friend. 

Bran, very likely, Sam is his companion now.

Jorah, Sam’s new pal. Wouldn’t be an easy choice for Jorah since he felt he owed his life to Dany (who convinced him to find a cure from greyscale) and Sam (who actually saved him). However, I believe he would not stay still when Sam is in danger. 

And don’t forget Gilly. She is very protective of him too. She stood up against Lord Tarly when he harshly criticized Sam when he returned to Horn Hill. She would not let Sam be bullied in front of her.

He’s a greater warrior than either of you would ever be. (Gilly to Lord Tarly when he insulted Sam, 6x06)

I’m angry that horrible people could treat good people that way and get away with it. (Gilly to Sam about how his father treated him, 6x06)

I always wonder why Gilly was featured among the final significant characters on EW while other seemingly more important ones such as Yara Greyjoy or Gendry didn’t make it. There should be a reason. And I’m doubtful the reason is just that she is Sam’s girlfriend and her son is the human brother of the Night King’s White Walkers. 

Gilly knows, or at least partly knows the truth about Jon’s true parentage. She found out the records about the annulment between Rheagar Targaryen and Eila Martell and his secret marriage to Lyanna Stark. I don’t rule out the possibility that she blurts it out in a moment of anger and vulnerability. Or Sam himself would do it. 

Which leads to an even bigger mess. 

# 4  Everyone knows Jon is the heir to the Iron Throne, jeopardizing Dany’s claim

Since Jon’s parentage, Westeros’ biggest secret, would have a huge impact on the plot, I bet it will be revealed to the public in the most dramatic way possible, and at the worst timing possible. It has to burst out when all the tensions and distrusts between various parties present in Winterfell accumulate and peak while the Dead is marching close. Which moment could be worse than that? 

The choice each character makes in this critical moment will reveal who they truly are and what they really want: a blindly selfish being or someone with heart and reasons. That’s why I believe all these dramas will happen shortly before the Dead Army reaches Winterfell. Within the limit of this post, we would not discuss the impact of Jon’s parentage becoming public knowledge on Jon, the Starklings, the Northen lords and the Lannisters. We focus on Dany, her choice when knowing it, thus affecting Jorah’s choice. 

Dany would not take it lightly. For someone who spent her entire existence believing that she’s the rightful ruler of the Seven Kingdoms, and that the Iron Throne is hers by right, just to receive the news that she’s behind Jon in the line of succession, that news itself is a killer blow. Sometime before or after Jon’s parentage revelation, Dany will also know about Cersei’s betrayal too, and she will get desperate. She fears she’s losing everything. In the South, Cersei is taking back the lands she conquered. The North does not accept her. And her supposed lover is actually another contender for the Throne (and he does not look like he’s truly in love with her either). She would feel that she has sacrificed everything while gaining nothing. So now she has to face the most difficult choice in her life: Stay or Go. And so Jorah also has to face the most difficult choice in his life: follow his Queen or stay in the North.

Jon or Dany? His father’s successor or the queen he adored?

It’s for sure a painful, messy and difficult choice for Jorah. He’s been in love with Dany and protecting her all along, from the time she was a timid princess walking into a forced marriage with Khal Drogo until she becomes the powerful “goddess” queen of today. He swore to protect her ‘till his last breath. And I believe, under a different circumstance, if Jorah learns that Jon has hurt or “used” Dany in any sense, he’d kill Jon if he could. I totally expect that he would confront Jon, they might engage in a heated argument, even a fight probably.

“He’s been given the greatest challenges around Dany. He’ll be tested like never before.” (Ian Glenn about Jorah in S8, EW interview)

But in such very moment, when the Night King is coming close, it’s not about the fight for the Throne any more. It’s about the living and the dead. Jorah was with Jon beyond the Wall and both nearly lost their lives there (I think this is a deliberate choice from the writers for Jon and Jorah both almost died falling). He knows very well what would happen to everyone (including Dany, no matter she stays or leaves) if they don’t band together. 

Jon is for sure on the side fighting for the living, as he always insists. 

There’s only one war that matters. The Great War. (Jon, 7x07)

Gif:  itsbriankinney 

How about Dany? Would she stay and fight for the living no matter what? By now, she would feel betrayed by everyone, that her “sacrifice” is for nothing. And she fears that she loses the Throne to either Cersei or Jon, which she is no way willing to give up.

Jorah’s choice between Jon/Sam and Dany now becomes the choice between to fight for the living or to fight for the Throne.

And that’s when the memories of Lord Commander Mormont and what he has lived and died for come into play. Jon and Sam, those who continue Lord Mormont’s legacy are the living memories of Jorah’s father.

“Jorah, do you think it matters who sits on the Iron Throne?” 

Jorah would feel his father whispering in his ears. He broke his father’s heart once, disgracing and abandoning his family. Going South with Dany now would mean he abandons his family in the hardest time, leaving them freeze to death, and betrays the memories of his father. 

And so it becomes the choice between…

Father’s memories or the love for a woman

In the books, Lord Mormont died on the way back to the Wall with Sam. His dying wish was for Jorah to take the black, i.e. to continue his fight for the living. 

“Tell my son. Jorah. Tell him, take the black. My wish. Dying wish.”

“Tell Jorah. Forgive him. My son. Please. Go.”

Samwell II, A Storm of Swords

In the show, Lord Mormont died in Craster’s Keep and he didn’t have enough time to tell anyone his dying wish. I guess the writers chose not to include this detail in the show because it would be too revealing that Jorah will end up choose to continue his father’s fight over any other fight. Or they want show!Jorah’s choice of fighting for the living is entirely his, out of the love for his father. However, in any case, the hint to Jorah’s final decision is already there. 

To this point, the love and trust Jorah has for Dany has become a wall with numerous cracks. Can it be mended or will it finally tumble down? That will be the topic of the final installment of this series.

-to be continued-

What did he say to Dany when trying to convince her not to order the execution of thousands of masters in Yunkai when they rised against her?

Moreover, Jorah insisted that if building a better world was what Dany wanted, she had to show people (from both sides) another way, different from the brutality they had always known.

The slaves you freed, brutality is all they’ve ever known. If you want them to know something else, you’ll have to show it to them. (Jorah to Dany, 4x07)

reblog.comment:
Part 1

Part 2

In part 1, we speculated the events that might soon happen once Dany arrived North (#1 Dany’s dragons and/or the Dothraki do some harms to the Northerners; and #2 Tensions between Dany and the Northern lords including Lyanna Mormont because of #1) causing the first cracks in Jorah-Dany relationship.

In part 2, we revisited the life of Lord Commander Mormont, Jorah’s father and the father figure to both Jon and Sam, whose life and dedication practically bonds Jorah with his father’s two surrogate sons. We also examined how the relationship with their respective father (Ned, Jeor, Randyll) and the desire to carry the ancestral sword (Ice, Longclaw, Heartsbane) shaped Jon, Jorah and Sam’s character development and would be another bonding factor between the three sons. It’s highly likely that Sam will bestow his ancestral sword Heartsbane to Jorah. And this act of kindness will boost up Jorah’s morale and motivation to fight for the side of the living, to honor his father, and to pay his debt to Sam. 

Bromance or Romance, Family or Khaleesi

As discussed in part 1, tensions in the North between Dany and the lords would escalate shortly after her arrival while the Dead Army is approaching. Everyone starts to be wary of Dany and her dragons. And to boil up the already messy situation: 

# 3 News about Dany roasting the Lannister army and the Tarlys reaches the North

One way or the other, the lords will know about how Dany dracarys-ed the Lannister army and forced the survivors to kneel by executing the Tarlys with fire. Most probably from the maesters in Citadel who have been in contact with maester Wolkan in Winterfell. Everyone will be shocked, bad memories of the Mad King and all the terrible Targaryen rulers before him will be recalled and distrust of Dany and her “good will” would grow exponentially. 

Imagine what Jorah would think when he knows that his beloved Khaleesi, who always claimed to make the world a better place and free people from oppression, has done this horrible thing to thousands of men, many of them are just innocent commoners who were dragged into someone else’s war. 

Gif:  mockingjaykatniss2

What did he say to Dany when trying to convince her not to order the execution of thousands of masters in Yunkai when they rised against her?

Moreover, Jorah insisted that if building a better world was what Dany wanted, she had to show people (from both sides) another way, different from the brutality they had always known.

The slaves you freed, brutality is all they’ve ever known. If you want them to know something else, you’ll have to show it to them. (Jorah to Dany, 4x07)

[[MORE]]

Mind you, he was explaining her why punishing thousands of slavers, who were obviously criminals was a bad idea. She listened to him in Meereen, but does the exactly the opposite in Westeros, where her opponents are no slavers, making her actions of brutalizing them even worse. And here’s how she takes his wise counsel to heart and shows the people something different from brutality?? 

Gif:  urvi531

Jorah has to be totally disappointed at his ability as an adviser by now.

He would not be cool with the knowledge that Dany had slaughtered thousands of soldiers with a rain of fire while she obviously could win the battle without deploying her dragon. Not to mention what happened in the aftermath, when she continued to threaten the prisoners and executed their generals with dragon fire. To instill fear and force submission. His trust and respect in Dany would gradually deteriorate. 

Note that due to his leave to find a cure for himself, Jorah was not present in both scenes where Dany introduced herself as a fierce, merciless warlord. The writers kept him out for a reason. They want to reserve his reactions for a later date when the news and/or the reality would shock him. Jorah would shudder when he knows how brutal Dany has become and he cannot be at ease at all, if Dany plans to keep her word and does exactly the same to the North.

Like when she gave her rousing speech to the Dothraki about “kill my enemies in their iron suits and tear down their stone houses”…

Gif:  yocalio

… and the infamous “bend the knee or die”…

Does she sound any more like the compassionate queen who aspired to build a better world for the downtrodden that he once believed in? Does she sound any less brutal than all the sh*t leaders he already knew throughout the course of history?

Now Jorah knows exactly what Dany would do to those who do not kneel. He would be more worried than ever for the Little Bear since she might be in direct confrontation with Dany on various issues. Moreover, he would be very ashamed of himself and his Queen, and feel indebted to Sam, the one who saved his life and honored him with the Tarlys’ ancestral sword.

If the maesters in Citdel didn’t have the heart to inform Sam, then Jorah would find it a hundred time harder to face his savior after this news breaks out.

Despite his difficult relationship with his father, I bet Sam would be horrified and devastated when he learns about the fate of his father and brother. And I don’t believe he would keep his cool and stay silent “for the greater good”. Very likely, Sam will confront Dany, question her decision and/ or demand an explanation/ apology from her. I’m not sure if he would take a more reckless action toward Dany, but whatever he does, Sam puts himself in a very dangerous position when he personally confronts the Mother of Dragons.

When all these chaos happen, Jorah would try to give Dany counsel and calm her down (like he always did). But now Dany has fully embraced her identity as a dragon (as Lady Olenna advised her), she wouldn’t listen to him any more. 

And this is when Jorah finally sees Dany for what she is: A Dragon.

They’re dragons, Khaleesi. They can never be tamed. (Jorah to Dany, 4x01)

Dragons don’t know the difference between what is theirs and what isn’t. (Jorah to Missandei, 7x07)

This whole situation will be a hot mess, since lots of people in Winterfell had awful experience and/ or memories with fire fanatics. Jon, Davos, Tormund, Sansa, Arya, Bran, Gendry, Sandor, all the Northern lords, etc. And if Sam is under threat from Dany, who would find themselves responsible to protect him?

Jon, of course, Sam is his best friend. 

Bran, very likely, Sam is his companion now.

Jorah, Sam’s new pal. Wouldn’t be an easy choice for Jorah since he felt he owed his life to Dany (who convinced him to find a cure from greyscale) and Sam (who actually saved him). However, I believe he would not stay still when Sam is in danger. 

And don’t forget Gilly. She is very protective of him too. She stood up against Lord Tarly when he harshly criticized Sam when he returned to Horn Hill. She would not let Sam be bullied in front of her.

He’s a greater warrior than either of you would ever be. (Gilly to Lord Tarly when he insulted Sam, 6x06)

I’m angry that horrible people could treat good people that way and get away with it. (Gilly to Sam about how his father treated him, 6x06)

I always wonder why Gilly was featured among the final significant characters on EW while other seemingly more important ones such as Yara Greyjoy or Gendry didn’t make it. There should be a reason. And I’m doubtful the reason is just that she is Sam’s girlfriend and her son is the human brother of the Night King’s White Walkers. 

Gilly knows, or at least partly knows the truth about Jon’s true parentage. She found out the records about the annulment between Rheagar Targaryen and Eila Martell and his secret marriage to Lyanna Stark. I don’t rule out the possibility that she blurts it out in a moment of anger and vulnerability. Or Sam himself would do it. 

Which leads to an even bigger mess. 

# 4  Everyone knows Jon is the heir to the Iron Throne, jeopardizing Dany’s claim

Since Jon’s parentage, Westeros’ biggest secret, would have a huge impact on the plot, I bet it will be revealed to the public in the most dramatic way possible, and at the worst timing possible. It has to burst out when all the tensions and distrusts between various parties present in Winterfell accumulate and peak while the Dead is marching close. Which moment could be worse than that? 

The choice each character makes in this critical moment will reveal who they truly are and what they really want: a blindly selfish being or someone with heart and reasons. That’s why I believe all these dramas will happen shortly before the Dead Army reaches Winterfell. Within the limit of this post, we would not discuss the impact of Jon’s parentage becoming public knowledge on Jon, the Starklings, the Northen lords and the Lannisters. We focus on Dany, her choice when knowing it, thus affecting Jorah’s choice. 

Dany would not take it lightly. For someone who spent her entire existence believing that she’s the rightful ruler of the Seven Kingdoms, and that the Iron Throne is hers by right, just to receive the news that she’s behind Jon in the line of succession, that news itself is a killer blow. Sometime before or after Jon’s parentage revelation, Dany will also know about Cersei’s betrayal too, and she will get desperate. She fears she’s losing everything. In the South, Cersei is taking back the lands she conquered. The North does not accept her. And her supposed lover is actually another contender for the Throne (and he does not look like he’s truly in love with her either). She would feel that she has sacrificed everything while gaining nothing. So now she has to face the most difficult choice in her life: Stay or Go. And so Jorah also has to face the most difficult choice in his life: follow his Queen or stay in the North.

Jon or Dany? His father’s successor or the queen he adored?

It’s for sure a painful, messy and difficult choice for Jorah. He’s been in love with Dany and protecting her all along, from the time she was a timid princess walking into a forced marriage with Khal Drogo until she becomes the powerful “goddess” queen of today. He swore to protect her ‘till his last breath. And I believe, under a different circumstance, if Jorah learns that Jon has hurt or “used” Dany in any sense, he’d kill Jon if he could. I totally expect that he would confront Jon, they might engage in a heated argument, even a fight probably.

“He’s been given the greatest challenges around Dany. He’ll be tested like never before.” (Ian Glenn about Jorah in S8, EW interview)

But in such very moment, when the Night King is coming close, it’s not about the fight for the Throne any more. It’s about the living and the dead. Jorah was with Jon beyond the Wall and both nearly lost their lives there (I think this is a deliberate choice from the writers for Jon and Jorah both almost died falling). He knows very well what would happen to everyone (including Dany, no matter she stays or leaves) if they don’t band together. 

Jon is for sure on the side fighting for the living, as he always insists. 

There’s only one war that matters. The Great War. (Jon, 7x07)

Gif:  itsbriankinney 

How about Dany? Would she stay and fight for the living no matter what? By now, she would feel betrayed by everyone, that her “sacrifice” is for nothing. And she fears that she loses the Throne to either Cersei or Jon, which she is no way willing to give up.

Jorah’s choice between Jon/Sam and Dany now becomes the choice between to fight for the living or to fight for the Throne.

And that’s when the memories of Lord Commander Mormont and what he has lived and died for come into play. Jon and Sam, those who continue Lord Mormont’s legacy are the living memories of Jorah’s father.

“Jorah, do you think it matters who sits on the Iron Throne?” 

Jorah would feel his father whispering in his ears. He broke his father’s heart once, disgracing and abandoning his family. Going South with Dany now would mean he abandons his family in the hardest time, leaving them freeze to death, and betrays the memories of his father. 

And so it becomes the choice between…

Father’s memories or the love for a woman

In the books, Lord Mormont died on the way back to the Wall with Sam. His dying wish was for Jorah to take the black, i.e. to continue his fight for the living. 

“Tell my son. Jorah. Tell him, take the black. My wish. Dying wish.”

“Tell Jorah. Forgive him. My son. Please. Go.”

Samwell II, A Storm of Swords

In the show, Lord Mormont died in Craster’s Keep and he didn’t have enough time to tell anyone his dying wish. I guess the writers chose not to include this detail in the show because it would be too revealing that Jorah will end up choose to continue his father’s fight over any other fight. Or they want show!Jorah’s choice of fighting for the living is entirely his, out of the love for his father. However, in any case, the hint to Jorah’s final decision is already there. 

To this point, the love and trust Jorah has for Dany has become a wall with numerous cracks. Can it be mended or will it finally tumble down? That will be the topic of the final installment of this series.

-to be continued-

If the maesters in Citdel didn’t have the heart to inform Sam, then Jorah would find it a hundred time harder to face his savior after this news breaks out.

Despite his difficult relationship with his father, I bet Sam would be horrified and devastated when he learns about the fate of his father and brother. And I don’t believe he would keep his cool and stay silent “for the greater good”. Very likely, Sam will confront Dany, question her decision and/ or demand an explanation/ apology from her. I’m not sure if he would take a more reckless action toward Dany, but whatever he does, Sam puts himself in a very dangerous position when he personally confronts the Mother of Dragons.

When all these chaos happen, Jorah would try to give Dany counsel and calm her down (like he always did). But now Dany has fully embraced her identity as a dragon (as Lady Olenna advised her), she wouldn’t listen to him any more. 

And this is when Jorah finally sees Dany for what she is: A Dragon.

They’re dragons, Khaleesi. They can never be tamed. (Jorah to Dany, 4x01)

Dragons don’t know the difference between what is theirs and what isn’t. (Jorah to Missandei, 7x07)

This whole situation will be a hot mess, since lots of people in Winterfell had awful experience and/ or memories with fire fanatics. Jon, Davos, Tormund, Sansa, Arya, Bran, Gendry, Sandor, all the Northern lords, etc. And if Sam is under threat from Dany, who would find themselves responsible to protect him?

Jon, of course, Sam is his best friend. 

Bran, very likely, Sam is his companion now.

Jorah, Sam’s new pal. Wouldn’t be an easy choice for Jorah since he felt he owed his life to Dany (who convinced him to find a cure from greyscale) and Sam (who actually saved him). However, I believe he would not stay still when Sam is in danger. 

And don’t forget Gilly. She is very protective of him too. She stood up against Lord Tarly when he harshly criticized Sam when he returned to Horn Hill. She would not let Sam be bullied in front of her.

He’s a greater warrior than either of you would ever be. (Gilly to Lord Tarly when he insulted Sam, 6x06)

I’m angry that horrible people could treat good people that way and get away with it. (Gilly to Sam about how his father treated him, 6x06)

I always wonder why Gilly was featured among the final significant characters on EW while other seemingly more important ones such as Yara Greyjoy or Gendry didn’t make it. There should be a reason. And I’m doubtful the reason is just that she is Sam’s girlfriend and her son is the human brother of the Night King’s White Walkers. 

Gilly knows, or at least partly knows the truth about Jon’s true parentage. She found out the records about the annulment between Rheagar Targaryen and Eila Martell and his secret marriage to Lyanna Stark. I don’t rule out the possibility that she blurts it out in a moment of anger and vulnerability. Or Sam himself would do it. 

Which leads to an even bigger mess. 

# 4  Everyone knows Jon is the heir to the Iron Throne, jeopardizing Dany’s claim

Since Jon’s parentage, Westeros’ biggest secret, would have a huge impact on the plot, I bet it will be revealed to the public in the most dramatic way possible, and at the worst timing possible. It has to burst out when all the tensions and distrusts between various parties present in Winterfell accumulate and peak while the Dead is marching close. Which moment could be worse than that? 

The choice each character makes in this critical moment will reveal who they truly are and what they really want: a blindly selfish being or someone with heart and reasons. That’s why I believe all these dramas will happen shortly before the Dead Army reaches Winterfell. Within the limit of this post, we would not discuss the impact of Jon’s parentage becoming public knowledge on Jon, the Starklings, the Northen lords and the Lannisters. We focus on Dany, her choice when knowing it, thus affecting Jorah’s choice. 

Dany would not take it lightly. For someone who spent her entire existence believing that she’s the rightful ruler of the Seven Kingdoms, and that the Iron Throne is hers by right, just to receive the news that she’s behind Jon in the line of succession, that news itself is a killer blow. Sometime before or after Jon’s parentage revelation, Dany will also know about Cersei’s betrayal too, and she will get desperate. She fears she’s losing everything. In the South, Cersei is taking back the lands she conquered. The North does not accept her. And her supposed lover is actually another contender for the Throne (and he does not look like he’s truly in love with her either). She would feel that she has sacrificed everything while gaining nothing. So now she has to face the most difficult choice in her life: Stay or Go. And so Jorah also has to face the most difficult choice in his life: follow his Queen or stay in the North.

Jon or Dany? His father’s successor or the queen he adored?

It’s for sure a painful, messy and difficult choice for Jorah. He’s been in love with Dany and protecting her all along, from the time she was a timid princess walking into a forced marriage with Khal Drogo until she becomes the powerful “goddess” queen of today. He swore to protect her ‘till his last breath. And I believe, under a different circumstance, if Jorah learns that Jon has hurt or “used” Dany in any sense, he’d kill Jon if he could. I totally expect that he would confront Jon, they might engage in a heated argument, even a fight probably.

“He’s been given the greatest challenges around Dany. He’ll be tested like never before.” (Ian Glenn about Jorah in S8, EW interview)

But in such very moment, when the Night King is coming close, it’s not about the fight for the Throne any more. It’s about the living and the dead. Jorah was with Jon beyond the Wall and both nearly lost their lives there (I think this is a deliberate choice from the writers for Jon and Jorah both almost died falling). He knows very well what would happen to everyone (including Dany, no matter she stays or leaves) if they don’t band together. 

Jon is for sure on the side fighting for the living, as he always insists. 

There’s only one war that matters. The Great War. (Jon, 7x07)

Gif:  itsbriankinney 

How about Dany? Would she stay and fight for the living no matter what? By now, she would feel betrayed by everyone, that her “sacrifice” is for nothing. And she fears that she loses the Throne to either Cersei or Jon, which she is no way willing to give up.

Jorah’s choice between Jon/Sam and Dany now becomes the choice between to fight for the living or to fight for the Throne.

And that’s when the memories of Lord Commander Mormont and what he has lived and died for come into play. Jon and Sam, those who continue Lord Mormont’s legacy are the living memories of Jorah’s father.

“Jorah, do you think it matters who sits on the Iron Throne?” 

Jorah would feel his father whispering in his ears. He broke his father’s heart once, disgracing and abandoning his family. Going South with Dany now would mean he abandons his family in the hardest time, leaving them freeze to death, and betrays the memories of his father. 

And so it becomes the choice between…

Father’s memories or the love for a woman

In the books, Lord Mormont died on the way back to the Wall with Sam. His dying wish was for Jorah to take the black, i.e. to continue his fight for the living. 

“Tell my son. Jorah. Tell him, take the black. My wish. Dying wish.”

“Tell Jorah. Forgive him. My son. Please. Go.”

Samwell II, A Storm of Swords

In the show, Lord Mormont died in Craster’s Keep and he didn’t have enough time to tell anyone his dying wish. I guess the writers chose not to include this detail in the show because it would be too revealing that Jorah will end up choose to continue his father’s fight over any other fight. Or they want show!Jorah’s choice of fighting for the living is entirely his, out of the love for his father. However, in any case, the hint to Jorah’s final decision is already there. 

To this point, the love and trust Jorah has for Dany has become a wall with numerous cracks. Can it be mended or will it finally tumble down? That will be the topic of the final installment of this series.

-to be continued-
trail.content_abstract:
Part 1

Part 2

In part 1, we speculated the events that might soon happen once Dany arrived North (#1 Dany’s dragons and/or the Dothraki do some harms to the Northerners; and #2 Tensions between Dany and the Northern lords including Lyanna Mormont because of #1) causing the first cracks in Jorah-Dany relationship.

In part 2, we revisited the life of Lord Commander Mormont, Jorah’s father and the father figure to both Jon and Sam, whose life and dedication practically bonds Jorah with his father’s two surrogate sons. We also examined how the relationship with their respective father (Ned, Jeor, Randyll) and the desire to carry the ancestral sword (Ice, Longclaw, Heartsbane) shaped Jon, Jorah and Sam’s character development and would be another bonding factor between the three sons. It’s highly likely that Sam will bestow his ancestral sword Heartsbane to Jorah. And this act of kindness will boost up Jorah’s morale and motivation to fight for the side of the living, to honor his father, and to pay his debt to Sam. 

Bromance or Romance, Family or Khaleesi

As discussed in part 1, tensions in the North between Dany and the lords would escalate shortly after her arrival while the Dead Army is approaching. Everyone starts to be wary of Dany and her dragons. And to boil up the already messy situation: 

# 3 News about Dany roasting the Lannister army and the Tarlys reaches the North

One way or the other, the lords will know about how Dany dracarys-ed the Lannister army and forced the survivors to kneel by executing the Tarlys with fire. Most probably from the maesters in Citadel who have been in contact with maester Wolkan in Winterfell. Everyone will be shocked, bad memories of the Mad King and all the terrible Targaryen rulers before him will be recalled and distrust of Dany and her “good will” would grow exponentially. 

Imagine what Jorah would think when he knows that his beloved Khaleesi, who always claimed to make the world a better place and free people from oppression, has done this horrible thing to thousands of men, many of them are just innocent commoners who were dragged into someone else’s war. 

Gif:  mockingjaykatniss2

What did he say to Dany when trying to convince her not to order the execution of thousands of masters in Yunkai when they rised against her?

Moreover, Jorah insisted that if building a better world was what Dany wanted, she had to show people (from both sides) another way, different from the brutality they had always known.

The slaves you freed, brutality is all they’ve ever known. If you want them to know something else, you’ll have to show it to them. (Jorah to Dany, 4x07)
